title: former-ross-high-pupil-ruari-paton-aiming-scottish-cup-glory
story: Ruari Paton will be hoping to line up for Stranraer todaywhen they make the long journey north to face Brora Rangers, who stunned Hearts in the previous round.The frontman attended the Tranent secondary school after signing for Hibernian as a teenager and making the move from Dublin.Many had expected Stranraer to be travelling to Tynecastle this weekend but Brora caused one of the biggest shocks in the competitionrsquos history when they won - last Tuesday.Paton was part of the Stranraer team taking on Brechin City at the same time and said that his reaction was much the same as football fans up and down the country when he heard the result.He said: ldquoI would not like to take anything away from Brora but you donrsquot really hear of a Championship team getting beaten by a Highland League or a Lowland League team ever.ldquoIt was a shock, it was a big shock, but fair play to them.ldquoWhat an achievement it is and it is an amazing challenge to overcome.ldquoYou cannot take anything away from them.Stranraer have enjoyed an impressive start to the campaign, with just one defeat since the beginning of November, as they look toto League One.Paton, who now lives in Bothwell, South Lanarkshire, has been at the heart of that form, scoring eight goals in all competitions, with strikes against Spartans and a last-minute penalty winner against Kelty Hearts in the previous round.He has also found the net for Gala Fairydean Rovers, while on loan from Hibs, and for East Kilbride in the competition last year.Now, attention has turned to the trip to Brora and Paton said: ldquoTherersquos nothing better in the world than scoring. Any forward player will tell you that. If you have a terrible game and score a goal or play fantastic and not score ndash you are judged on your goals as a forward.ldquoHopefully, I will get another goal but I need to make sure I am in the team. I would love another goal and I love the Scottish Cup. I loved it with East Kilbride and Gala Fairydean Rovers ndash it is great and you love those big moments in competitions.Paton moved from Dublin to East Lothian after signing for Hibs around his th birthday.He lived with Helen Leslie and her two sons, Darren and Jonathan, off Tranentrsquos Waterloo Road and attended Ross High School, where he studied physical education, English and sports leadership.The striker was quick to praise both the family and the school for helping him develop. He said: ldquoThey took me in asI was part of their family.ldquoThey were absolutely fantastic to me and made me feel so welcome.ldquoI went for dinner with them and they were brilliant.ldquoIn my first year, I spoke to Sean McPartlin, education and welfare officer, and he askedI wanted to do something. I agreed to it and they said I would train some days.ldquoIt is the best thing I ever did.That saw Paton ide his time between attending school and training at Hibernian Training Centre at East Mains on the outskirts of Ormiston.The -year-old spent two years at the secondary school and told Courier Sport how much he enjoyed the experience. He added: ldquoIt was brilliant ndash the best thing I ever did, honestly.ldquoI was not too keen going to school at that age with football andI had not then I would not have made many friends. The amount of people I met through school was unbelievable.Paul Reynolds, headteacher of the Tranent secondary school, said: ldquoNot only was Ruari a standout footballer, he was a true gentleman.ldquoHe was always extremely polite and his positive attitude was infectious. I have rarely met someone so filled with optimism.ldquoWith his lsquogo get lsquoemrsquo attitude, he settled into Ross High School very quickly and it was a pleasure to have him here. Irsquom delighted to hear that he is still playing and wish him all the very best.

title: plans-second-substation-former-cockenzie-power-station-site-lodged-council
story: The latest planning application, from Seagreen Wind Energy, shows a substation built on top of a former gasholder site stretching across paths which the firm admits may have to be erted.Seagreen sparked local concern when its initial consultation appeared to put the entire Greenhills in its proposed site.However, the plans now lodged with the council show the substation across the road from the former Cockenzie Power Stationrsquos main footprint on an old gasworks area now being used for a temporary car wash business.Acknowledging concerns raised by community councils over the loss of green space, Seagreenrsquos application says: ldquoAs far as possible, the proposed substationwill be sited to avoid any areas of habitat value. Where not possible, we confirm that any potential loss of woodland or scrub would be compensated for by post-construction landscape planting.And they added that any loss of existing footpaths was still to be discussedto agree how to mitigate it, adding: ldquoThis will likely involve a ersion to the existing footpath. If this is required, we will seek to minimise theof this ersion as far as possible.Seagreen currently has apoundbn offshore wind farm development under construction after it was granted exclusiverights for the Firth of Forth Zone of the UKrsquos Round  offshore wind farm development programme.Phase One within the zone includes the development of two offshore wind farms ndash Seagreen Alpha and Seagreen Bravo ndash located more than km from the Angus coastline.Work is already under way to bring the energy online at a number of sites, with Cockenzie the latest to be put forward.The former Cockenzie Power Station site was bought by East Lothian Council from ScottishPower after the stationrsquos iconic chimneys were demolished.It has been marketed by the local authority for projects, with a visionary masterplan setting out a wide range of employment, energy and recreational uses for the large -hectare site and surrounding area.To date, a substation which will bring energy onshore for Inch Cape Offshore Ltd is the only proposal given planning permissionfor the site.Seagreenrsquos proposals cover a nearby area of land outwith the power station footprint itself, including a beach car park next to it, where underground cables would be brought on land, under the main road and into the National Grid inshore.The proposal includes an onshore substation, underground electricity cables and ldquotemporary and permanent infrastructure to export electricity.

title: musselburgh-churches-helping-food-donations-pandemic
story: Musselburgh Baptist Church opens its foodbank every Thursday morning between am and noon, while St Andrewrsquos High Church members have been helping out East Lothian Foodbank.Ross McNab, assistant pastor at the baptist church, said it was ldquoamazing that the congregation was back together meeting in person since the end of March, adding that the church wanted to extend ldquoa warm welcome to our wider community to come join us.He added: ldquoWe are meeting together every Sunday and currently hold three services at am, .am and noon. Each service lasts approximately one hour and contains a mixture of music, teaching and prayer.ldquoTo help us follow current guidelines and maintain a safe environment, booking is required. To book a seat, please get in touch via info@musselburghbaptist.org or message us through our Facebook page , where we also livestream our .am service.The Rev Dr Leslie Milton, minister at St Andrewrsquos High Church, said: ldquoWe have had a particular focus on supporting East Lothian Foodbank throughout the pandemic and members were active in Resilient Musselburgh while it was operating.ldquoOur morning worship is at am in church and on Facebook. We hold an additional service on a Tuesday afternoon once a month for those who are unable to come out in the morning.ldquoWe have a weekly coffee morning and occasional discussion groups on Zoom. We are now livestreaming the services. We are also able through Facebook and the weekly email to include people who find it hard to get to church. The weekly email with the full service and the livestream services will continue even after all restrictions are lted.ldquoWe are surprised and delighted by the way many older people have embraced technology and social media.

title: spectators-welcomed-back-musselburgh-racecourse-later-month
story: In a carefully managed event, the East Lothian track will admit  racing fans in the first steps towards lting Covid- restrictions and resuming normal racing.The racecourse has worked closely with the East Lothian Safety Advisory Group to establishing a raceday protocol, which can be amended as further restrictions are relaxed in the weeks ahead.At the afternoon meeting on May , alcohol and food can only be ordered and must be consumed at tables in a designated picnic area, while a two-metre distancing rule will be enforced throughout the course.The racecourse has also confirmed that its popular Stobo Castle Ladies Day has been moved from August  to Friday, August , to maximise the enhanced safety benefits from the Governmentrsquos objective of having every adult vaccinated by the end of July.A crowd limit for what is traditionally a sell-out event will be set once it becomes clear what restrictions, , any might be in place in August.Bill Farnsworth, Musselburgh Racecourse general manager, said: ldquoIt has been a very challenging year for Musselburgh and all Scottish racecourses, and while our instinct is to welcome back as many racing fans as possible, we are erring on the side of caution by opting to admit only  visitors are our next meeting.ldquoThe measures we have put in place underline that the safety of our guests, racing industry personnel and our staff must come first, but we will use the meeting on May  as a template for going forward.ldquoNo doubt we will learn what works best for hosting a race day for the general public against the backdrop of Covid- restrictions."We are confident we can offer an entertaining afternoon of live sport with ample space around the course to allow visitors to socially distance.Mr Farnworth stressed that no bars or restaurants would be open and that food and alcohol would only be served at a designated seated picnic area. Visitors will not be allowed to enter the grounds with their own picnics.He added: ldquoMoving Stobo Castle Ladies Day to August  is simply to give us the best chance of hosting our most popular race meeting in a more relaxed environment, and given that most people should by then have received their vaccinations, this should add an extra layer of comfort for racegoers.Guests who have already booked Ladies Day admission tickets for August  have been informed of the change of date and been issued refunds, and they will prioritised when rebooking for the August  event.In June, Musselburgh hosts three racedays, including The Edinburgh Cup Raceday on Saturday, June , two afternoon meetings in July, and in August a further four meetings, including Stobo Castle Ladies Day. The racecourse will release details for these fixture as the relaxation of Covid regulations develops.Tickets for the race meetings on May  and June  go on sale on Thursday at am and are expected to sell out quickly.For a full fixture list and to book tickets, visit musselburgh-racecourse

title: musselburgh-north-berwick-swimming-pools-open-week

title: covid-recovery-first-focus-says-new-east-lothian-msp-paul-mclennan
story: Paul McLennan won the county seat for the SNP as he defeated Labourrsquos Martin Whitfield, the Conservativesrsquo Craig Hoy ndash both of whom are now South Scotland MSPs ndash and Euan Davidson of the Liberal Democrats.MSPs are sworn in at the Scottish Parliament today , with Mr McLennan ndash who has risen through the ranks from community councillor in Dunbar to former East Lothian Council leader to MSP ndash keen to look to the future.Speaking on Tuesday morning, Mr McLennan, who is also a ward councillor for Dunbar and East Linton, said: ldquoI think for me, the whole focus for the next wee while is going to be Covid recovery.ldquoThere are three main areas for me, including economic recovery.ldquoThat has been good so far and I have got a real feel for where businesses are.ldquoI chaired the town centre group on the council and we have a meeting where we talk about tourism, the town centre and the general economic position. We do that every week and that is the key thing now: getting businesses open.ldquoTourism is a major part of that and there will be another announcement hopefully to see more reopening.ldquoWe have just got to try to support tourism, leisure, hospitality, town centres and the broader economic recovery.Mr McLennan, who is exploring how to donate his councillor salary to a local charity while an MSP, has already been in discussions with Lesley Brown, executive director of education and childrenrsquos services at East Lothian Council, about the educational recovery in the wake of the pandemic.He stressed that it was not just about the next six months or even a year but looking beyond that.Similarly, Mr McLennan, who lives in Dunbar with we Sharron, was keen to work with the NHS in its recovery.Labour had held the East Lothian seat since the Scottish Parliament was formed in , with John Home Robertson and then Iain Gray representing the county for more than  years.However, , people voted for Mr McLennan last Thursday, with Mr Whitfield finishing in second spot on ,.The victor told the Courier his phone had ldquonever stopped ringing with people congratulating him ahead of his first trip to Holyrood as a newly elected MSP.He said: ldquoIt felt a bit surreal but the overriding thing is it is incredibly humbling just thinking about the amount of support.ldquoI am really determined now with people putting faith in myself and the SNP it is up to me now to go and repay that faith.ldquoI am very proud of what we achieved and really looking forward to getting into the business of parliament.The election count was held on Friday at Meadowmill Sports Centre, near Tranent, with coronavirus restrictions in place.Mr McLennan, who plans to have a constituency office set up this summer, said he and the party were ldquocautiously optimistic as the day wore on but it was too close to call as to who would come out on top.The four candidates were then invited into a room and told the result before it was made public.Mr McLennan, who has lived in Dunbar all his le and previously worked with the Bank of Scotland on the townrsquos High Street, took time to thank those who had helped him during the campaign but also singled out someone who could not be there, his dad Jim, who died two years ago.He said: ldquoI could not drive until I was about  for ious reasons.ldquoMy dad used to drive me to surgeries and to meetings sometimes.ldquoHe died from dementia two years ago and in his last few years he could hardly talk but I remember he said: lsquoThatrsquos my son, he is a councillor.rsquoldquoWhen I was elected to East Lothian Council in , it meant so much to him and he was one of the first thoughts I had on Friday.ldquoI was thinking about my dad andhe had been there.Mr McLennan, who previously served on Dunbar Community Council, became a councillor in  when he was elected as one of three members of the Dunbar and East Linton ward.The father-of-two, whose son Scott is a coach at Heart of Midlothian FC and daughter Kirsty works with Musselburgh catering and events firm Hickory, is now looking forward to working alongside both Mr Whitfield, who was previously East Lothian MP from  to , and Craig Hoy, who is a councillor, representing the Haddington and Lammermuir ward.Mr McLennan, who has vowed to stay on as a councillor until next yearrsquos local authority elections, said: ldquoI think voters had a really good choice of experienced candidates ndash Martin is an ex-MP and Craig being a councillor ndash which made winning even more rewarding for myself.ldquoThere are guidelines for constituency and list MSPs and what they can do but we can work together in delivering for East Lothian.ldquoI congratulate both of them and look forward to working with them.

title: get-coronavirus-tests-east-lothian-asymptomatic-next-week
story: A permanent testing centre is now open at the former Stoneyhill Community Centre in Musselburgh, found near Musselburgh Rugby Club.It is open Tuesdays-Saturdays from am to pm no appointment is required.The facility is open to residents from across the county as long as they have no coronavirus symptoms, including a fever, cough, or loss or change of taste or smell. Those with symptoms must book their test at one of the dedicated testing centres for those displaying symptoms.Alongside this, a number of mobile testing units will be open and operational across several towns. Most are open am-pm.Tomorrow , Saturday and Sunday, the mobile testing units will be at the Loch Centre in Tranent and at Dunbar Leisure Pool.On Monday, they will be at both Prestonpans and Longniddry Community Centres. The unit at Longniddry closes at pm.On Tuesday, Wednesday and next Thursday , the mobile testing units will be at The Mercat Bar and Grill in Whitecraig and at the Port Seton Centre.Then next Friday, Saturday and Sunday , the units will be at the Loch Centre in Tranent and Dunbar Leisure Pool.Residents can also order home testing kits and have them delivered to their home. See gov.scot for more information.People can get tested more than once and can also attendthey have already received a coronavirus vaccine.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoThe virus still presents a risk. Almost one in three people who have Covid- donrsquot have any of the usual symptoms but are potentially passing the virus on to loved ones and people in the community. Thats why local arrangements are in place for people without symptoms to get tested.ldquoThis means people can find outthey are positive and take immediate action to stop the spread of the virus to others by self-isolating.

title: get-paid-drink-beer-thanks-musselburgh-universitys-study
story: Itrsquos looking for  people to take part in a consumer taste trial where they will sample the beer.Run by the universityrsquos Scottish Centre for Food Development and Innovation, the team is recruiting  people who are already stout drinkers ndash those who enjoy the occasional pint of Guinness, Belhaven Black or Murphyrsquos ndash as well as  who have not drunk stout before but are keen to try it.Recruitment for tasters starts now, with the trial to begin later this month.Each participant who completes tastings and provides the necessary feedback will be rewarded with a pound John Lewis or Amazon voucher as a thank you for taking part.Participants, ideally from Edinburgh and the Lothians, will be asked to pick up samples from the university and will be given two sample stout recipes to taste at home. They will need to complete an online questionnaire to provide feedback and highlight their preferred sample. Access to the internet is essential and the feedback process is believed to take about - minutes to complete.Catriona Liddle, who heads up the Scottish Centre for Food Development and Innovation, is running the trial.She said: ldquoOur consumer tasting  are extremely popular with foodies and people from the local community who enjoy sampling and talking about food and drink. Itrsquos open to people who are already part of our existing consumer , but itrsquos also an opportunity for new people who might like to get involved in further food and drink tasting .ldquoWe normally have multiple sessions running on campus each week across all food types. The only consideration is that sadly we cannot accept any applications from those with food allergies or food restrictions.ldquoThe samples on this trial will be blind tested, so participants wonrsquot know which type of stout they are tasting, and we will be using the results to help create Scotlandrsquos favourite stout.Email the food team at consumer@qmu.ac.uk to apply.Participants must be aged  and over.

title: plans-lodged-scenic-cottage-overlooking-firth-forth
story: A holiday let cottage is already in place above Canty Bay, to the east of the town, but a developer has applied to East Lothian Council for planning permission for a new building on the site to replace the existing property.A design statement for Ryan Lothian, who is behind the proposals, said: ldquoThe proposal explores the replacement of an existing dwelling in Canty Bay which, despite regular maintenance over the last  years, has reached the end of its natural lespan and is no longer habitable.Earlier this year, a condition survey carried out at the cottage found it ldquoin a poor condition with penetrative damp and decaying timbers.The new cottage would replace the existing property, which dates back to before the Second World War.The design statement continued: ldquoThe existing two-bedroom cottage is deemed uninhabitable and is in a severely deteriorating condition.ldquoTherefore the proposal is to replace the existing cottage with a contemporary dwelling that nestles into the surrounding landscape.ldquoThe proposed replacement dwelling is of a similar size, scale and massing to the existing cottage and responds positively to the local context in order to protect and enhance the coastal character and quality of landscape.

title: scotland-home-year-inside-katie-spiers-home
story: ldquoI didnrsquot really have TV in my mind, says Spiers, , ldquoit wasnrsquot something I thought I would ever do. Irsquove always been happy with my online job and content creation, but when I went for a meeting with the team, I just loved them ndash they were so passionate about the show, and I just thought lsquookay, letrsquos try it out!rsquoThe popular home show continues to attract a strong following in its third series,Spiers believes demand will be at an all-time high. ldquoI think itrsquos a really great programme to go on after so long in lockdown, she highlights.ldquoWhen everyonersquos been looking at the same four walls for the last year, lots of people have big plans for what theyrsquore going to do with their homes, and for when they can have tradesmen back into the house, so I think watching an interiors show is going to be inspiring for people hellip a welcome bit of voyeurism.Despite the fluctuating restrictions of the pandemic last year, the crew, alongside Spiersrsquos fellow judges interior designer Anna Campbell-Jones and architect Michael Angus, were able to film series three last September.ldquoI would not recommend filming during a pandemic, laughs Spiers. ldquoWe would do Covid tests every couple of days, get temperature checks twice a day ndash we constantly had thermometers hanging out of our mouths.ldquoWe were really lucky we could get out to film, and it was great to see more of Scotland.Originally from New Zealand, Spiers considers herself an honorary Scot since moving here as a child. The content creator has a weighty , followers on Instagram, many of whom were gained over the last year alone. ldquoMy following grew massively during the pandemic, she explains, ldquowhereas it hadnrsquot grown that much in the last couple of years.One of the main reasons for this influx is Spiersrsquos dreamy, aesthetically pleasing interiors.ldquoI would think my niche, or my USP, is probably that I live quite a simple le ndash I view my content as being attainable but slightly aspirational.ldquoMy husband and I live in a three-bedroom tenement flat in the southside of Glasgow ndash itrsquos far from a mansion, but it has period detailing and wersquove done a lot of work to make it our own and inject our personality into it. I think Irsquove created quite a colourful home that brings me a lot of joy.So, after being able to add TV presenter to her ever-growing CV, whatrsquos next for Spiers  ldquoWriting is my passion, she emphasises. ldquoI would love to write a book one day, a collection of essays, I think ndash thatrsquos something Irsquove always been leading up to. Although everybody always wants me to do an interiors book!Kate shares her top tips to freshen up your home for springThere is no better time to refresh your home than the start of a new season, and the arrival of spring definitely brings with it a chance to declutter and revive your space. So, throw open your windows, stock up on blossom-scented cleaning supplies and follow my steps for freshening up your home for spring hellipDeep clean and declutter:Spring is the perfect time to assess your home and see what you can donate or throw out. Then give everything a once-over as you go ndash spring cleaning is good for the soul.Have a room refresh: Changing the layout of a room and giving your home a bit of a rejig does wonders for making the space feel like new. Once or twice a year Irsquoll consider how I can switch up my spaces. Irsquoll move furniture, swap out soft furnishings, relocate the sofa to another position or change our spare room completely. Irsquoll even rework the gallery walls and artwork around my home. Itrsquos like redecorating but without spending a penny.Bring the outdoors: in Stock up on tulips, daffodils and peonies, and place bouquets around your home ndash on mantelpieces, sideboards, kitchen worktops and coffee tables. Irsquom a big fan ofgreenery in the home too ndash plants like Pothos, Monstera deliciosa and ZZ plants are so easy to take care of and really breathe a bit of le into a room. Irsquom all about the indoor jungle, so go wild with blooms and plants and your home will feel bright and breezy in no time.Consider a lick of paint: With so many fun paint brands launching lately , itrsquos easier than ever to add colour to your le. Opt for a fresh eucalyptus green to revive a bathroom, or pick a played-down pink for warmth. title: new-gps-nurses-call-handlers-join-riverside-medical-practice-musselburgh
story: Two new GPs, two nurse practitioners and two new call handlers have taken up jobs at the surgery since the start of the year, with a further GP due to arrive in the summer and two GPs due tofrom maternity leave.Recruitment for one more GP is ongoing, with a fresh recruitment push due to launch shortly to coincide with new GPs entering the workplace as their training comes to an end.Dr Richard Kitto, a long-standing doctor at the practice, has been made a GP partner.The Courier has previously reported that the practice has come under fire from frustrated patients who have complained about dficulties contacting it to secure appointments.Commenting on the recruitment drive, Dr Richard Fairclough, GP partner, said: ldquoWe must stress to all of our patients and stakeholders in the local community that this remains an exceptionally busy time for general practices all over the country. Our successful recruitment is good news but wersquore now ndash with the exception of one GP, a nurse practitioner and the further call handlers ndash at the limit of the number of people we can employ at the practice yet we estimate that demand for appointments will still outweigh our capacity to provide them.He explained: ldquoWe must therefore continue to stress the urgent need for the full implementation of the  GMS Contract, which lays out the ious types of care due to be removed from the remit of general practice, in order to allow GPs to provide the expert medical care to the local community that we so desperately want to be able to do.He added: ldquoThis is widely recognised to be a challenging time to recruit GPs, with more GPs leaving the Scottish workforce each year than new GPs entering it.ldquoSo given this, wersquore especially delighted to welcome our two new GPs to the practice. Dr Maeve Chestnutt joined us from the Forth Valley Practice in March after relocating to East Lothian and Dr Michael Slowey has joined us last week from a practice in Sussex after locuming with us for a short time.He continued: ldquoWersquod also like to extend warm congratulations to Dr Kitto, who joins myself, Dr Cameron and Dr Stenke as a GP partner.Dr Fairclough said: ldquoTheirs arenrsquot the only new faces at the practice this year. Senior nurse practitioner Chris Gent has joined us as clinical manager from NHS , bringing his considerable clinical and operational experience to Riverside, along with nurse practitioner Sarah Miller.ldquoFinally, wersquore so pleased to welcome a further two new call handlers to our reception team, with more to follow shortly. Being a GP receptionist is such a challenging role, requiring a deep knowledge of how the surgery works, as well as calmness under pressure, and outstanding customer service skills. We know our two new recruits are going to make a great contribution to our now -strong reception team.

story: A BID to ban booze in a North Berwick park was being proposed, reported the East Lothian Courier on May , .An alcohol exclusion zone could be created in North Berwick as part of a joint police and community initiative to curb underage drinking in town.Plans are underway to ban alcohol from the Lodge Grounds public park ndash a popular haunt for teeny tipplers.A similar scheme is already operating in several streets in Prestonpans ndash the first town in the district to introduce no-go areas for public drinking ndash and police in North Berwick are keen to follow suit.They hope to get the backing of nearby residents and the local community council before taking the idea to East Lothian Licensing Board for formal approval.The matter was discussed at the monthly meeting of North Berwick Community Council on Tuesday.Sergeant Alistair McIntyre warned that banning the drinking of alcohol in the park could push the underage tipplers to other areas of the town, possibly the harbour.FIVE generations of the same family were in attendance at a baptism in Dunbar, told The Haddingtonshire Courier on May , .When baby Kathleen Lorimer was baptised in Dunbar Parish Church, her father, grandfather, great-grandfather and great-great-grandfather were there to watch the ceremony.The occasion marked the first time the five generations had gathered together.Baby Kathleen Vanessa is the daughter of Mr Tom Lorimerand his we, Avril.Her grandfather, Mr John Lorimer, gardener, and his we Chris, were there, as were her great-grandfather, Mr Tom Lorimer, a foreman with North Berwick Town Council, and his we Jean.The eldest member of the party was -year-old Mr John Lorimer.TWO men appeared in court after stealing planks of wood from a mine, as reported in The Haddingtonshire Courier on May , .On Friday, at Haddington Sherf Court, Peter Devannah, labourer and John Devannah, miner, both from Tranent, pleaded guilty to having on Saturday rd April, stolen four planks of wood from the pithead of Bankton colliery.The Fiscal said that the accused and another man were seen carrying planks up the railway line from the pit.When the police followed them, they made off.The accused were overtaken, but the third man escaped.They were taken back to the pit and admitted having stolen the wood.They were each fined s.

title: tims-book-road-legends-chapter-14-great-wood-caledon
story: FINN walked by the side of Lochan nam Arm, peering into the water in his search for Robert the Brucersquos sword. Then, something caught his eye.He ran to Izzy: ldquoAunty, aunty, look what I found!He was holding a scarf.ldquoIt was hanging on a tree over there, he said.It was a short neck scarf, with Celtic interlacing design it looked new and unworn, possibly even handmade.ldquoI really love it aunty, can I keep it Izzy pursed her lips in thought.ldquoI dunno, Finn, someone may have dropped it and another person found it and placed it on the tree to keep it safe. Perhaps one of those walkers earlier. Maybe they will come back and look for it Finn wasnrsquot even half listening. He put the scarf on and rushed to the loch side to look at his reflection.ldquoIt would be safer round my neck surely  he called out.As he arranged the scarf, a folded piece of paper fell to the ground and landed by Finnrsquos feet. He picked it up, unfolded it and ran to Izzy, very excited.ldquoLook, the scarf is for me! he exclaimed.A worried look came over Izzyrsquos face as Finn handed her the piece of paper. There were beautully drawn Celtic designs, with images of what looked like faeries hiding in a wood.There was also a sleeping dragon curled round a heart shape in which there was handwriting: ldquoIf you have found me, and you like me, then Irsquom yours. Keep me safe, until itrsquos time to give me away.Izzy looked at Finn, nodded and smiled. ldquoSo it seems.ldquoI will never give this away! he insisted. He looked around at the trees and ed the gaze to his aunt.ldquoMaybe yoursquore right, aunty, maybe fairies do exist after all, at least here we are in the Highlands after all.He thought for a moment. ldquoOr maybe itrsquos just someone kind who likes to give presents.Finn headed back to the tree where hersquod found the scarf. He arranged twigs and broken bits of heather on the ground next to the tree and beckoned his aunt to come see.She looked down at what hersquod done. She didnrsquot immediately see it, but then realised that the twigs and heather formed letters.He carefully read it: ldquoThank you.ldquoThatrsquos lovely Finn, whoever left the scarf will see this and be very happy, Irsquom sure of it.Izzy looked up to the sky. The predicted rain was going to hold off.ldquoFinn, she said hesitantly, ldquowould you be up for a bit of an adventure ldquoYou mean a walk, donrsquot you ldquoKind of, aye, but this is to a place I have never been before, although Irsquove often seen it from a distance.ldquoHow far  asked Finn.Izzy pointed: ldquoJust there, where those old trees are. Itrsquos a small remnant of the old Caledonian forest, Irsquove often wanted to visit it but have never had the opportunity. Itrsquos not so far, but it might be a bit dficult to reach, Irsquove never explored it before.Finn wasnrsquot sure.Izzy helped him decide: ldquoIt might have a connection to the original Merlin.That sold it to him.ldquoWell, I have my boots, he smiled, ldquocan I lead the way So they set off in the direction of Coille Coire Chuic, a small remnant of the ancient Caledonian forest. Izzy let Finn decide on the route and as they neared the wood they arrived at the River Cononish. There was no obvious and safe way to cross, but Izzy was sure there was a small bridge downriver.The route got increasingly boggy and Izzy suspected Finn may want to give up, but instead he took the role of leader seriously and carefully planned each step, identying dryer patches and helping his aunt. They made slow progress, but with much hilarity as they balanced on small tufts of dry land surrounded by bog myrtle.Finn paused and listened. The noise of a waterfall could be heard ahead and he aimed for it. Izzy lagged behind to take in the beauty of the heather, which carpeted the ground with a blaze of purple and pink. The old Scots pines on the other side of the river looked magnicent, framed by the mountains beyond.She caught up with Finn, who was sitting on a rock watching the waterfall. It cascaded into a hidden pool, where the water twirled and bubbled asin a giant cauldron. Scots pine trees stood guard on the edge of it, one growing precariously from the overhanging rocks, its trunk curving upwards so its higher branches reached the sunlight. A gnarled rowan with vivid berries grew from the rocks on the other side, while on the opposite bank birch trees clung onto the steep side of the river, bent over like weeping willows.Finn wanted to sit awhile and so Izzy took it as an opportunity to make a brew for them both. He was beginning to understand that using her small camping stove was an important ritual for his aunt: the hissing sound, the waiting, the trail of steam, the anticipation it made a warm feeling, turned a wild place into home.They sipped tea together and shared well-earned snacks. Finn waited, expecting his aunt to tell a story. Finally, she did.ldquoSee that giant boulder over there, Finn, it was dropped by the giants who sculpted this land many years ago.ldquoLike with Samsonrsquos stone we saw Izzy nodded.Finn raised a cynical eyebrow and half a smile.ldquoHuge giants, Finn, a race called the Fomorians. The legend says they emerged from the sea long ago ndash grotesque troll-like creatures, incredibly powerful and cruel. Two of them made Rannoch Moor their home and they terrorised the people for miles around, destroying homes and taking livestock.ldquoNobody knew what to do, even the bravest and best warriors were defeated by them, ripped apart without mercy. Then a young lad about your age had his home destroyed by one of the giants, and in his grief he decided to rid the land of them.ldquoBut how could he do thateven the best warriors couldnrsquot Izzy gave him a wry smile, which he knew meant that was a good question and that she was just about to answer it.ldquoThe lad was wise. He had noticed how the two giants argued with each other about who was the stronger.ldquoSo he got them to fight each other ldquoKind of, he persuaded them to have a competition to see who could throw a stone furthest. They began hurling bigger and bigger stones, then they tore chunks of rock off the mountain sides. Soon the land was littered with boulders, and after three days the two giants were utterly exhausted.ldquoThen the young lad told one of the giants he had won, for he knew this would cause a fight. And so it did.ldquoThe giants fought each other with fury, using up what energy they had left. Finally, one gave the other a fatal blow, but it was the last thing he did, as he collapsed with total exhaustion.ldquoThey had killed each other ldquoYes, smiled Izzy, filling her cup with more tea and raising it. ldquoThatrsquos why the land around here is littered with all these huge stones.ldquoI know giants are mythological, aunty.Izzy sipped some tea.ldquoDepends what kind of giants you mean.Finn looked at the boulder.ldquoThe next tale is the gt of the sun, continued Izzy.ldquoAfter the death of the giants the land was bathed in sunshine, bringing new le.It became a green world, grass and plants grew, then trees arrived. The ancestors of this tree were first to arrive, she pointed to the nearby silver birch.ldquoOthers followed: the rowan, the aspen, alder and even oak. But it was these trees which made the forest canopy: Scots pines, also called Caledonian pines, an old name given to them by the Romans. Arenrsquot they a beautul tree Finn peered at the Scots pines around them.ldquoCreatures filled the forest with their songs, their roars, their grunting and howling the birds, bears, wolves, elk, deer and boar. Seven thousand years ago, where we sit we would have been amidst the Caledonian forest in its prime. Those trees over there are the descendants of that forest. If you sit with them and feel their presence, they will tell you their stories.Finn chuckled at his aunt, then explained why. ldquoYou are like Yoda! He defensively held up his hands to explain: ldquoNot the way you look, I mean the way you speak about things.Finn was a Star Wars fan. He had all three films on video at home and knew much of the dialogue by heart. He spoke to Izzy, mimicking Yodarsquos voice: ldquoSearch the force, le creates it, makes it grow, its energy surrounds us and binds us, luminous beings are we. Finn gently pinched Izzy on the shoulder, saying: ldquoNot this crude matter. You must feel the force around you, the tree, the rock, everywhere.Izzy laughed out loud, feeling rather flattered to be compared to one of Finnrsquos screen heroes. She thanked him for the compliment.Finn looked over at the old Scots pines on the other side of the river. He knew his aunt wanted to reach them and they were tantalisingly close, yet the river was too dangerous to cross.ldquoLetrsquos find a way to get there, he ventured.They packed up and followed the river, eventually finding a place to cross. They sat amidst the flowering heather under the canopy of old trees, near a clearing so a light breeze kept the midges at bay. As promised, Izzy spun legends of Merlin, but also other tales connected to the ancient forest: of Lailoken, the Picts and St Columba, and the sad tale of the last wolf. Finn added tales of his own, about Jedi Knights and what he could remember of the story of Tam Linn. The forest was both their theatre and audience. But there was a sense of melancholy in this wood, for something was missing: it was bereft of young trees. The old pines were missing their children.The walk back was much quicker and they arrived back at the car tired, but with a sense of achievement. It felt asthey had been in a dferent world.ldquoCan we camp tonight aunty  asked Finn. ldquoAnd have a campfire like the first night ldquoLetrsquos see how the weather holds and how we feel later, she replied, keeping options open.Food was now a priority and Izzy was keen to get away from the busyness of Tyndrum. Soon they were on their way, heading for Loch Tulla, where she planned to make their tea. She knew Ewen would already be at the Bridge of Orchy. What she didnrsquot know was his mum was with him, Finnrsquos grandmother, whom Finn had loved so much.She was waiting with her son in his car, literally trembling with emotion, desperate to see her beloved grandson, whom she hadnrsquot seen for more than four and a half years.Here are the links to chapters one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, , ,  and .

story: Roadworks on the A, between the Thistly Cross and Abbotsview junctions, mean that the road will be closed from pm on May  until am the following day.A spokesman for Bear Scotland confirmed that work was being carried out by Keltbray on behalf of ScottishPower.He said that Keltbray had produced a statement, which reads: ldquoKeltbray, on behalf of ScottishPower, are carrying out essential work on a section of overhead lines between May  at pm to May  at am which will result in the closure of a section of the A.ldquoThis will include work on the high voltage and low voltage networks, changing electricity poles and overhead power cables.ldquoWe are replacing and refurbishing equipment which is coming to the end of its serviceable le, which is essential works to make sure we maintain a good quality of supply for our customers.ldquoA ersion route will be in place.ldquoAccess for emergency vehicles will be maintained at all times.

title: bbcs-money-nothing-salvages-items-kinwegar-recycling-centre-wallyford
story: Salvage superhero Sarah Moore was at the East Lothian Council-run site at Kinwegar recently to pick up unwanted goods, give them a new lease of le and turn them into cash for their original owners.The presenter spoke to three East Lothian men ndash two from Musselburgh and one from Elphinstone ndash who arrived at the skips to dispose of the three items.They were delighted to hand them over to her and appear on the programme, which was aired on BBC last month.Michael Clague, the owner of the four-man tent, from Musselburgh, said it was ldquopast its use-by date.He said: ldquoIrsquom just glad the tent is going to be recycled as it was sitting in our garage for some time.Sarah took it to award-winning bag maker Neil Wragg, who turned the old tent into  tote bags, which were sold to people all over the country via social media.Sarah visited the Honest Toun to hand over pound to Michael, who said he would use the cash for a homecoming for his son, who was at sea, and donate some to the Tranent-based Walk with Scott Foundation to help with its charity work.Another Musselburgh man, Alan, was getting ready to throw away a glass-topped coffee table. He and his partner felt it might not now be safe with grandchildren around the house.Sarah took the ldquoretro restoration project to East London-based, award-winning wallpaper, textile and surface designer Daniel Heath, who transformed the table with a custom screenprint design, and spray etch pattern on new toughened glass.Sarah again visited the original owner at his home in Musselburgh to hand over pound profit after the tablersquos sale to a furniture and interior shop in Northumberland. Alan said he planned to treat his grandchildren to a day out with the money he received.An old miniature greenhouse, brought to the centre by George, from Elphinstone, and believed to be an lsquoapprenticersquo piece dating from the s, was rescued to be worked on by Sarah herself at her West Sussex base.ldquoItrsquos a shame to put it in the skip but Irsquom trying to clear out, George said.Sarah went on to turn it into ldquoa vintage greenhouse with a bit of quirkiness by adding new panes of clear and coloured perspex to create a stained glass effect. She filled the fully al greenhouse with plants, selling it to a private buyer via social media.Back at his home in Elphinstone, a delighted George received pound from the sale, which he planned to give to his two sons.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoWe were very pleased that the programme chose to visit our recycling centre, which provides a valuable service to local residents.The programme can be viewed at bbc programmes mvl

title: historic-dunbar-methodist-church-saved-public-use
story: Dunbar Methodist Church ndash the oldest existing Methodist church in Scotland ndash dates back to .However, in , the congregations of Dunbar Methodist Church and nearby St Annersquos Scottish Episcopal Church merged and began meeting at the latter.The Victoria Street building was later sold, with developer Monkscroft Properties Limited keen to ensure that ldquothe building remained in use as a public space and as an asset for the community of Dunbar.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department has given the go-ahead to change the building into a venue for weddings, s and community use.Ewan McIntyre, who is behind the scheme, was delighted to see progress being made.He said: ldquoThe best reason to buy the building was to make sure it did not get turned into housing. It is part of the fabric of Dunbar.Minimal changes are planned for the building, with replacement steps outside.The main church space has capacity for about  people for worship, with the developers looking to host ldquosmall and intimate weddings, with a reduced capacity of up to  people seated for lunch or dinner and up to  people in total for ceremonies and celebrations.Stained glass windows have been repaired, while other decoration has been completed inside the building.Members of the public will get the chance to look around the venue on May  and  at an open door event.However, the proposals did not win favour with everyone in the town.The planning department received three letters objecting to the plans, with concerns that there would be loud music played at the venue, disturbance with people congregating before, during and after events, and worries about where people attending events would park their cars.During the planning process, the applicants highlighted ldquorelationships with neighbours are crucial to the success of the venue and the utmost care will be given to managing guests and noise.Dunbarrsquos community council was among those who backed the proposals when they were first lodged with the local authority in summer last year.Pippa Swan, community council chairwoman, was pleased the scheme was progressing.She highlighted that the building was not listed and it could have been demolished or transformed to make way for housing.She was pleased the building would remain in community use.Mrs Swan said: ldquoWe are absolutely thrilled.ldquoI know that the Methodist church building, when it was a place of worship and dwindling congregation, was an uphill struggle to keep the building in good repair.ldquoIt is fantastic that it has got a new owner and wonderful it is being kept as a place of public assembly.

title: tranent-fundraiser-taking-two-double-marathons-walk-walk
story: Margaret MacLeod, , took up marathon running at the age of , and has now completed six official Walk The Walk lsquoOver The Moonrsquo events, which see participants complete  miles in less than  hours.While walkers of the virtual Over The Moon this year are being given a longer, -hour time limit, Margaret has decided to push herself to stay within  hours.The Tranent resident, who will be completing the virtual event on Saturday, said: ldquoItrsquos a huge challenge.ldquoI can walk a marathon in just under six hoursIrsquom really pushing it, and I can run one in just under five itrsquos like running a marathon at your top speed the whole time.Last year, the Walk The Walk fundraiser was cancelled entirely and this yearrsquos has been forced to go virtual, due to Covid ndash but that hasnrsquot stopped the intrepid Winton Close resident, who last year walked  laps of her house for the challenge.She said of this yearrsquos event: ldquoI thoughtI did laps nearby, I could get people to come and walk a lap with me.ldquoAnd before I knew it, I had a wee team!Margaret, a receptionist in the investment industry by day, will be joined on her double marathon journey round the .-mile route by  dferent friends, who will each complete a lap of the route with her.This year, the theme of the event is lsquoOut Of This Worldrsquo, which would usually be illustrated by participantsrsquo decorated bras. But, says Margaret, she is ldquothe worst sewer ever.She told the Courier: ldquoI have no imagination so my bra has just got a wee bit of fringing and some wee glitzy bits. Itrsquos just glammed.And Margaretrsquos two adult sons have mixed feelings about their inspirational mumrsquos athletic achievements. While one ran with her for her first marathon ndash ldquoa challenge for my th birthday according to Margaret ndash the other is not quite as hands-on.She said: ldquoMy younger one ran with me dressed as Elsa from Frozen, so hersquos extremely supportive but the older one just grunts at me: lsquoGood on you, mum.rsquoBut Margaret is pushing ahead with her challenge ndash inspired and supported, she says, by Haddington Running Club ndash despite her own reservations about walking in her bra in daylight.She said: ldquoIrsquom putting myself out there for breast cancer. title: east-lothian-council-midlothian-council-dalkeith-custody-ends
story: Police Scotland has revealed plans to stop staffing the cells at the station, making it an lsquoancillaryrsquo centre which will only be used during major events or as back-up.The move will mean people arrested in East Lothian and Midlothian, who would have been taken into custody in the Midlothian station now face being transported to St Leonardrsquosin Edinburgh for lock-up.A meeting of East Lothianrsquos Police, Fire and Community Safety Scrutiny Committee, was told that the proposals would free up two additional local police officers for the county.However, concerns were raised by councillors about the additional journey time it would take for officers to transport people in custody to the Edinburgh station.Suzie Mertes, from Police Scotlandrsquos Criminal Justice Services ision, said that the number of people being taken into custody in Scotland had halved from , to , in recent timesand changes were being made as part of an annual review.She told the committee that providing custody services at St Leonardrsquos would be better for prisoners who might be vulnerable as more support services were available and would benefit local officers who were currently drafted in to ldquobackfill for custody officers when they were on leave.It was not made clear whether the decision to take custody officers away from Dalkeith would see opening hours of the station reduced or changed.However, Ms Mertes stressed that the custody facilities would not close completely and would be available for major events in the area or times when it was felt they were needed.And she said that current custody staff based at Dalkeith would be given the option to transfer their services to support local policing.She added: ldquoIn terms of Dalkeith, should someone need to be brought in for an interview it will be open.ldquoThis is a flexible model that will allow us to push and pull resources into Dalkeith when needed.Concerns were raised about the additional journey time for officers transporting prisoners to St Leonardrsquos for custody however, Ms Mertes said that the benefits outweighed the disadvantages, pointing out that officers could sometimes find themselves manning empty cells at Dalkeith when they could be spending time on local policing.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, committee convenor, said that the move could prove beneficial to those who found themselves spending a night in the cells as well.And the decision was welcomed by the committee convenor to downgrade Dalkeithrsquos custody centre from a full-time operation to lsquoancillaryrsquo.He said: ldquoThere are some concerns that there is movement towards the centre of Edinburgh but there may be some benefit for the poor souls taken into custody.ldquoIf they are released from Dalkeith, getting back to North Berwick is an absolute nightmare, whereasthey are released from St Leonardrsquos, getting back to North Berwick is substantially easier.

title: east-lothians-jamie-ramsay-cycling-across-uk-80-days-drum-support-olympics
story: Jamie Ramsay had planned to travel to the international showcase last year, cycling and sailing the whole way from London to Tokyo.But the coronavirus pandemic saw the event pushed back  months, with Jamie, from Whittingehame, now going on a journey with a dference.It will see him complete  days of socially distanced cycling around the UK through June and July.The -year-old, sponsored by Whole Earth , said: ldquoIrsquom disappointed not to be able to go the whole way to Japan but am really looking forward to meeting fellow Team GB supporters in Scotland and around Britain.ldquoWersquore all in this pandemic together and need a bit of fun. I hope my passion and determination to do this challenge will get people in Scotland behind our Team GB heroes and show the benefits of exercise and nutrition on positive mental attitude and wellbeing.The journey will take Jamie ndash who has previously cycled from Sao Paulo in Brazil to Boliviarsquos La Paz, and run from Vancouver in Canada to Argentinarsquos capital city Buenos Aires ndash around Britain.The former Belhaven Hill, Stenton Primary and Loretto School pupil will pass through towns and cities twinned with or named after places along his original route, including Moscow in East Ayrshire and Holland in Hampshire.Instead of ending up in Tokyo, he will be crossing the finishing line in lsquoStokeyorsquo, also known as Stoke-on-Trent.Visiting Team GB athletesrsquo families, schools and fans en route, Jamie will record their cheers and waves on doorsteps, creating the biggest virtual Mexican wave to spur on Team GB hopefuls.His gruelling challenge will also see him climb Ben Nevis, cycle Hadrianrsquos Wall, and swim the Blue Lagoon in Abereiddy in south-west Wales.Last Tuesday, two-time Olympic rowing champion Helen Glover fired the starting gun from Londonrsquos  Queen Elizabeth Park to signal the start of Jamiersquos journey.Helen, who is aiming for a hat-trick of Olympic gold medals when the Games get under way in July, said: ldquoOur fans mean everything to us but wersquore now facing a Games this summer with no British spectators in Tokyo.ldquoJamiersquos epic journey to help get fans behind us is awe-inspiring.
