story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityWhen the fleet of  e-bikes and five stations was launched in November last year thanks to funding from The Vale of Glamorgan Council, it became the first public electric bike share scheme in Wales.Now thanks to its success, funding has been made available to expand the scheme into Dinas Powys.An online public consultation is being launched by nextbike today , where people can say where they would like to see a station installed and why.Nextbike UK MD, Krysia Solheeim, said: ldquoThe scheme has proved incredibly popular to date, with more than , journeys made and , km cycled so far."Thanks to its success, we want to expand the station network to allow convenient access to even more people.ldquoBike share schemes can have such a positive impact on peoplersquos lives in many ways, from the physical and mental health benefits that cycling brings, to the reduction in congestion and CO emissions that comes from cycling instead of using motorised transport.MORE NEWS:ldquoWersquore really keen to hear from the public about where they would like to see the new stations situated. Our bike share schemes are there to benefit the whole community, which is why we want to hear from as many people as possible.Nextbike docking stations have to be close to popular destinations such as existing transport links, job centres, supermarkets and other shops be in an area of high footfall be highly visible and easy to find have enough space to allow safe movement of pedestrians and people with limited mobility and be accessible by van or bike trailer to allow the nextbike service team to maintain the bikes and stations.     Final decisions will be made based on the above criteria, in addition to the ability to get power to the locations, which is determined by power providers.Councillor Peter King, Cabinet Member for Neighbourhood Services and Transport Vale of Glamorgan Council, said: ldquoThe nextbike e-bike hire scheme in Penarth has proved extremely successful."Since its launch, the hire of the bikes has been steadily increasing.ldquoWith the onset of summer, we have implemented a new docking station at Cosmeston, and very soon there will be a new docking station in Sully."I am convinced the scheme will only go from strength to strength.ldquoTwo additional docking stations in Dinas Powys will complement the existing nextbike network within the Vale of Glamorgan and provide an additional sustainable transport link between these three areas."I would encourage Dinas Powys residents to respond to the consultation as itrsquos important they are located where they are accessible to as many people as possible.Penarthrsquos existing stations are located at the Esplanade, Llandough Hospital, Windsor Road, Penarth Train Station, the Barrage and the recently-installed Cosmeston.While the Penarth bikes can currently only be rented and ed to Penarth stations, the ambition is to eventually link the scheme to nextbikersquos Cardf fleet, meaning commuters will be able to use the e-bikes to make the journey between the town and the city with ease.E-bikes are a combination of a conventional bike with a motor that take some of the effort out of pedalling for the rider. With top speeds of km per hour, the e-bikes can cover greater distances in less time and with less effort than conventional cycles.E-bike rental costs pound per  minutes for customers with a monthly or annual membership, or pound per  minutes on a pay as you ride basis.The consultation runs until May . He was just one of a kind and will be sorely missed.     Stuart was a good family man. He married Janet, a NHS nurse, and they had a wonderful daughter Rhinna, whom he absolutely adored.Sadly, during the last couple of years his health had deteriorated, though he made brave efforts to carry on trying to help the struggling rugby club. At the end of October he had a stroke while driving his car and ended up in hospital, where the Covid- lockdown prevented him from seeing his family for several months, which left him very upset and both Janet and Rhinna heartbroken. ldquoHe lost ten stones in weight and seemed to have aged  years in  days, explained his daughter.Thankfully, he was determined to see his loved ones and say goodbye, as Rhinna explained, so he resolutely battled against the odds, making sure he was able to see them by the end of April when the lockdown was relaxed.ldquoHe has waited for us," said Rhinna. potentially lethal danger".Where is the India iant dominant Surge testing has been under way in parts of Bolton since  May, after Public Health Englandconfirmed the town is one of the main locations of the India iant, which was reclassied as a lsquoiant of concernrsquo last week.Cases of the iant in England increased from  to  as of  May, according to PHE figures, with almost half of these related to travel or contact with a traveller.The majority of cases of the India Covid strain are concentrated in the north-west of England, predominantly in Bolton, and in London.The iant is also thought to be the reason behind half of coronavirus infections in Bedford, Blackburn with Darwen and South Northamptonshire, although these outbreaks are still small.Greater Manchester Mayor Andy Burnham has submitted a request to the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation that all over-s in Bolton, along with the rest of the Greater Manchester area, are able to receive a Covid- vaccination ldquoto mitigate the risks of spread in those communities where we are seeing more transmission.     There are also around  to  cases of the India iant in parts of Scotland, including Glasgow, with these cases again connected to travel.The India Covid iant, officially known as B.., was first detected in India in October.It has been designated a ldquoiant of concern by PHE as it is thought to be at least as transmissible as the iant detected in Kent last year, known as B, which is now dominant in the UK.PHE said there is currently no evidence to suggest that the new Indian iant is more serious than previous mutations, nor is there evidence which indicates that this version of the Indian iant is resistant to current vaccines.Health experts said they ldquohavenrsquot seen any hint of a current Covid iant that can fully evade the effectiveness of vaccines.On Wednesday , the European he said: ldquoThe vaccines donrsquot  per cent prevent infection for people.ldquoWhat they do is, they almost  per cent prevent hospitalisation and serious illness.ldquoWe donrsquot know enough to story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityWelsh Labourrsquos Jane Hutt was re-elected for the sixth Senedd earlier this month - she has held the seat since the Welsh Parliament first formed  years ago. She is the only MS to have served as a Minister in every Welsh Government to date.Ms Hutt ndash who was a South Glamorgan County councillor for  years before first obtaining her Senedd seat in  ndash said: ldquoIt was a lovely outcome ndash itrsquos humbling that people have put their trust in me and Irsquom very grateful.ldquoItrsquos an honour to serve people for the next five years. Therersquos so much to do and Irsquom hitting the ground running.MS Hutt has campaigned for equality for many years she became the first National Co-ordinator of Welsh Womenrsquos Aid in  and was a founder of South Glamorgan Womenrsquos Workshop.ldquoI want safety for all people ndash men and women, said Ms Hutt, who has recently had meetings with Vale of Glamorgan councillors and other agencies about how to make all areas safe for people.Ms Hutt had engaged with Vale of Glamorgan residents throughout her years as an MS, with the coronavirus pandemic and effects of lockdown a concern for the community over the last year,ldquoItrsquos a very dficult time for people, said Ms Hutt."Irsquove been fortunate to serve in First Minister Mark Drakefordrsquos cabinet... and his approach is based on team-work and evidence - not just medical or clinical, but social."Every step of the journey Irsquove focused on the impact [of Covid] on communities, including BAME communities and those with disabilities.ldquoDetrimental issues affecting the community and the people within it are at the fore-front, but I also work with police and the PCC. We have regular discussions about the impact of Covid, and lockdowns, and the easing of restrictions.ldquoIrsquove been engaging with police and Vale of Glamorgan Council enforcement officers to protect our communities and encourage respectful visits to our beautul coasts.     Ms Hutt is also supportive of business lsquoboth large and smallrsquo ndash and has also shown her support for Barry Hospital - in  she campaigned against a planned closure of the -bed Sam Davies Ward at Barry Hospital.ldquoBarry Hospital does wonderful work," said Ms Hutt.The Sam Davies ward played an important role in the Covid pandemic and will continue to do so.Ms Hutt also praised volunteers in the Vale of Glamorgan - and across Wales - for the tremendous support theyve shown within their communities. Earlier this year she thanked a number of volunteers, including Cowbridge Male Voice Choir, for their efforts throughout the coronavirus pandemic.Ms Hutt also engages with young people and supported The Schools CouncilsRegulations  which meant all schools in Wales need a council, enabling pupils to discuss matters relating to school, education, or other areas of concern, and to make representations on these to the governing body and the head teacher."This has helped pupils interest in being citizens and engaging with politics," said Ms Hutt.During the Senedd  election - for the first time - people aged  and  were given the option to vote."It was lovely to meet families who has discusses parties and their manestos," said Ms Hutt."Many of the young people I spoke to had made up their minds [about who to vote for]. Im glad young people felt empowered. Theyve been very much focused on the impact of the pandemic, but theyre also looking out for parents and grandparents generations in a caring way."To the young people who went to their polling stations [to vote] thank you for taking initiative - we will move Wales forward."People have put their trust in me and I will continue to serve all people across all areas of the Vale of Glamorgan." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. Picture: PA Photo BBC Little Door  Warren Orchard.The Pact follows a group of work friends in the aftermath of the sudden death of their young brewery boss.Bound by a secret that will change their lives forever, they are drawn into a fragile pact of silence ndash but can they all cope with the web of lies that is forming Fraser ndash known for Breaking Bad, Traces and Better Call Saul ndash plays Anna, whose marriage comes under extreme pressure due to the pact with her friends.Her husband Maxis a police officer investigating the shocking death while being completely unaware that his we is linked to the case.:ldquoTheir lives are changed forever, Fraser said. ldquoThings start to spiral out of control, and Irsquom very interested in things spiralling out of control and exploring living in constant fear. story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityHedgehogs travel around one mile every night through our parks and gardens in their quest to find food and other hogs to mate with. If you have an enclosed garden you might be getting in the way of their plans.One of the main reasons why hedgehogs are declining in Britain is because our fences and walls are becoming more and more secure, reducing the amount of land available to them.Penarth Hedgehog Street will help to connect gardens allowing hedgehogs more space to breed, find food and keep them off the roads. This will form part of the national Hedgehog Street campaign.The project street map for the Penarth estate taking part in the schemeAs part of the project, residents will be able to borrow footprint tracking tunnels and camera traps to monitor and record the presence of hedgehogs.Emily Shaw, the Local Nature Partnership Co-ordinator for the Vale of Glamorgan, said the mission is to reconnect people in the Vale with nature.MORE NEWS:ldquoThe way we will do this is by developing a nature recovery network with partners, where we hope to engage the public, local community groups and organisations, as well as schools and businesses to take part in practical action for nature in their communities, she added.ldquoThe Valersquos LNP is one of several across Wales with each county hosting their own LNP and is part of a fantastic network through a project called LNP Cymru which is co-ordinated by the WCVA and funded by the Welsh Government.As part of Hedgehog Awareness Week, the Vale Local Nature Partnership has launched a new pilot hedgehog highways scheme on a residential estate in Penarth to encourage residents to create small holes in their fences to help hedgehogs move around more easily.     Residents will also be able to get involved in a citizen science project to help us gather data on Penarthrsquos local hedgehog populations.A free online talk is being held on Thursday, May , with Stephen Powles who set up a similar scheme in a small village in Oxfordshire.For more information head to https:www.eventbrite e creating-hedgehog-highways-in-the-vale-of-glamorgan-tickets-. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe letter, dated August  , showcases the writerrsquos opinion of his own work and his determination to get children reading.Librarian Christine Wotton said she wrote to Mr Dahl ldquospeculatively as a -year-old student as she was studying for a degree in literature and linguistics in the late s.The item has been handed a guide price of pound- by Derbyshire-based Hansons Auctioneers. vw,vw,px, px"The letter, from August , reveals the authorrsquos opinion of his own work The letter reads: ldquoNever shelter children from the worldhellip the lsquocontentrsquo of any childrenrsquos book is of no importance other than that it enthrals the child ndash and thus it teaches or seduces him or her to lsquolikersquo books and to become a fit reader ndash which is vitalthat child is going to amount to anything in later le.ldquoThe book-reading child will always outstrip the non-book-reading child in later le. There are very few messages in these books of mine.ldquoThey are there simply to turn the child into a reader of books.ldquoDamn it all, they are mostly pure fantasy. Have you read the latest one, Matilda ldquoIt seems to have broken every sales record in the history of hardback publishing.Explaining the history of the letter, Miss Wotton said: ldquoI stumbled across Dahlrsquos address listed in the back of an old library book. vw,vw,px, px"Miss Wotton wrote to Mr Dahl in the late s as a -year-old literature and linguistics student ldquoOn a whim I asked him questions which intrigued me regarding his style and attitude towards childrenrsquos literature, never really dreaming of a response.ldquoSo, I was amazed to receive a chatty double-sided, handwritten A reply, plus another dissertation which he lent me, presumably written in his famous garden shed, discussing the importance of reading for children and referring to his newly published book Matilda, now a movie and West End musical.     She added: ldquoAs he indicated himself, it was unusual for him to reply to letters like mine, so I really struck lucky.ldquoWith the happy-go-lucky optimism of youth, I donrsquot think I fully appreciated my good fortune.The letter is set to go under the hammer on June  in Hansonsrsquo specialist library auction at Bishton Hall in Staffordshire.Addressing her reasons for selling the letter, Miss Wotton said: ldquoIrsquove enjoyed and treasured the letter for over  years and the time has come to share it, for others to read and enjoy his wise words which are dashed off in his wonderfully inimitable, flamboyant style. vw,vw,px, px"Miss Wootton was not expecting a double-sided response ldquoAs the youngest of six children, I always battled with naughty decrepit hand-me-down hairy ponies, so proceeds will go towards a horse to compete whilst Irsquom still courageous enough and young enough to bounce a bit.ldquoI like to think Dahl, with his no-nonsense attitude, would approve of my get up and go.Commenting on the item, Jim Spencer, head of books and works on paper at Hansons, said: ldquoThis is important. Itrsquos unusual to see such conversational correspondence from a big name like this.ldquoMost autograph letters that come up for sale are typed, brief, almost generic responses.ldquoThis is quite dferent, it gives us an insight into Dahlrsquos creativity and craft, his passion for making reading fun, encouraging children to pick up books and take a love of literature with them throughout the rest of their lives.ldquoIrsquom guiding the letter at pound to pound, but it could easily spark a fierce bidding battle and run away for much, much more..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Letter revealing Roald Dahl us secrets to good storytelling to go under hammer article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. Paul added: “It’s been a long and dficult year for us all with restrictions affecting our daily lives.
